entry.title: Re: Inquiry on Allocation of Incidental Costs for Importe...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To allocate incidental costs such as customs clearance fees, unloading charges, and warehousing fees to imported raw materials in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can follow these steps:

1. CBC Scope Items

For this process, you should consider the following scope items:

  • Procurement of Services (22Z): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item covers the procurement process, including service procurement which can be used for incidental costs.
  • Direct Procurement with Inbound Delivery (2TX): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item includes the inbound delivery process, which is relevant for handling imported goods.
  • Manual Transportation Planning (6W2): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item is useful for planning transportation, which can include incidental costs.
  • Freight Settlement (6W4): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item deals with the settlement of freight costs, which can be part of the incidental costs.

2. Applications (Apps)

The process of allocating incidental costs can be executed in the following apps:

  • Create Purchase Order: Use this app to create purchase orders for the imported raw materials and include incidental costs as service items.
  • Create Supplier Invoice: This app is used to record the supplier invoices for the incidental costs.
  • Post Goods Movement: Use this app to record the receipt of goods and allocate costs to the inventory.

These steps will help ensure that incidental costs are properly allocated to the respective purchased raw materials, impacting inventory valuation and financial reporting.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To find the earliest inbound posting date and the latest outbound posting date for a product using CDS views, you can follow these steps:

Steps to Create CDS Views

  1. Identify Relevant CDS Views:

    • Use the View Browser app to search for CDS views that contain the fields you need. For inbound and outbound posting dates, you might consider using I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 which contains fields related to material documents and posting dates.

  2. Create a Custom CDS View:

    • Open the Custom CDS Views app.
    • Select I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 as your primary data source.
    • Add necessary fields such as Material, Plant, Posting Date, and any other relevant fields.
    • Use filters or calculations to determine the earliest and latest posting dates.

  3. Join with Other CDS Views:

    • If you need additional fields like Warehouse, you can join your custom CDS view with other views that contain these fields.

  4. Publish and Test:

    • Once your CDS view is configured, publish it and test using tools like Postman or directly within SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Example Code

Here is a simple example of how you might define a view to get the earliest and latest posting dates:

DEFINE VIEW Z_ProductPostingDates AS SELECT FROM I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 [Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...](https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-sap/comparison-of-report-development-in-3sl-2sl-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public/ba-p/13578738)
{
  key Material,
  key Plant,
  MIN(PostingDate) AS EarliestInboundDate,
  MAX(PostingDate) AS LatestOutboundDate
}
WHERE GoodsMovementType IN ('101', '261')
GROUP BY Material, Plant

Additional Resources

  • You can refer to SAP‚Äôs documentation or community blogs for more detailed guidance and examples.

If you need further assistance or a video tutorial, you might want to check SAP‚Äôs official learning resources or community forums. Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date

[1] Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...
[2] Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Lean Services Enablement in Commercial Project Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Commercial Project Management (CPM) provides functions that address the core business process requirements of companies that offer project-based services to their customers. These functions cover multiple processes in an end-to-end scenario spanning the selling, planning, execution, monitoring, and controlling of projects. A core aspect of this process involves the various resource types for carrying out financial activities like Activity, Expense, Human Resource, Material and Revenue.

The SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release introduces Lean Services in CPM which can be used as a resource type for carrying out the financial activities. This extends the earlier introduction of Lean Service Components within Project System (PS) delivered in SAP S/4 HANA 2023 FPS1, providing a seamless experience across both CPM and PS. This blog outlines the essential configuration steps and system prerequisites for activating and integrating Lean Services in CPM, thereby enabling efficient handling of external procurement.

Types of Lean Services

  • Planned Lean Services: Services for which the quantity and exact value is known at the time of creating the purchase requisition.
  • Unplanned Lean Services: Services for which the exact value is not known at the time of creating the purchase requisition. Instead of a fixed price, you enter a value limit that must not be exceeded.

CPM now supports the integration of both Planned and Unplanned Lean Services. This functionality is enabled through the steps described below:

Prerequisite Configuration

  • Define the Resource Types for Lean Service in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Define Resource Types.Figure 1: Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement
  • Assign the resource types to the plan scenario for which financial plan will be done in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types.Figure 2: Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement

Integration with Project System (PS)

The following frameworks in CPM now support Lean Services integration with PS:

Import Planned data to CPM: In order to import data from objects in Project System (PS) into a financial plan, add the import method in IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Methods.

Figure 3: Import Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Import Methods to Import Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Strategies.

Figure 4: Import Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Transfer Planned data to PS: In order to transfer planned data such as quantities, cost, or revenue to business objects in backend systems, add the transfer method in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Methods.

Figure 5: Transfer Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Transfer Methods to Transfer Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Strategies.

Figure 6: Transfer Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Add the import and transfer strategies to the plan scenario in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Version Types.

Figure 7: Link Plan Scenario to Version Types for Lean Services Enablement

Once the above configuration steps are completed, you can seamlessly import the planned data for Lean Service Components from PS, carry out your planning and send the planned data back to PS - just like any other resource type. 

The following example illustrates an end-to-end scenario starting with planning of Lean Service Components in PS followed by importing the planned data into CPM. Planning activities are then carried out in CPM and the planned data is transferred back to PS.

Planning of Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 8: Planning of Planned Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 9: Planning of Unplanned Lean Service Components in PS

 Planned data of Lean Service Components imported from PS to CPM successfully

Figure 10: Import Planned Data of Lean Services from PS into CPM

Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Figure 11: Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Transfer of Planned data from CPM to PS

Figure 12: Transfer of Planned Data of Lean Services from CPM to PS

Planned data transferred from CPM to PS successfully

Figure 13: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Planned Lean Service

 Figure 14: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Unplanned Lean Service

Additional Information

For more details on Lean Services, you may refer below links:

  • Planning Lean Services
  • Lean Service Enablement for Project Networks

entry.title: Simplifying Event Configuration with the "Not Contains" Operator for Job & Automation Monitoring
entry.content:
In Q2 2025, SAP Cloud ALM introduced an impactful feature in its Job & Automation Monitoring app: the Not Contains operator for the Job/Automation Name parameter. This addition is set to streamline Event Configuration, saving administrators' valuable time and effort.

 

Why "Not Contains" Matters

Previously, administrators faced challenges when trying to exclude specific job names from events. The process involved manually entering each job name with the "is not" condition, a tedious task.

Scenario 1: One-Time Jobs

Imagine you're an administrator managing a complex customer system, where unique jobs are scheduled to run once daily. These jobs are named with a static prefix, such as "TEST," followed by a dynamic value like the current date and time. For instance, you might see job names like Test2025081201000, Test2025081301000, and so forth. As these jobs accumulate daily, managing them can become quite a task.

Previously, if you wanted to set up a generic runtime event to ignore all these unique jobs, you faced a challenge. The system didn't allow you to use a pattern-based exclusion, such as ignoring all job names containing "TEST." Instead, you had to manually enter each job name into the filter using the is not condition. This meant updating the filter every day, which was not only time-consuming but also increased the risk of errors.

Thankfully, this new feature enables a more efficient approach. By using the not contains operator for the Job/Automation Name parameter, you can easily set up a filter to ignore all jobs with names containing "TEST." This means you no longer have to manually update the filter daily, saving you time and reducing the potential for mistakes.

Scenario 2: Specific Name Patterns

Imagine a customer system where a runtime event was defined for a set of jobs with names containing the pattern "FCFS." The threshold for these jobs was set at one hour, meaning that if any job with "FCFS" in its name exceeded this runtime, an alert would be triggered. However, the customer also wanted to establish a generic runtime event with a shorter threshold of 30 minutes for all other jobs.

Previously, users faced a significant hurdle: the system did not allow them to exclude jobs with the "FCFS" pattern from the generic runtime event. The only workaround was to manually enter each job into the filter using the is not condition, which was both time-consuming and prone to errors.

With this new feature, users can now easily set up alerts for jobs that do not contain "FCFS" in their names without the need for manual entry. This enhancement not only saves time but also reduces the risk of overlooking jobs that should be excluded from the generic runtime event.

 Embrace the Change

 The Not Contains operator is designed to speed up and improve event configuration. Whether you're dealing with one-time jobs or specific name patterns, this feature reduces hassle and enhances productivity. We encourage you to explore this new tool and experience the ease it brings to your workflow.

 Feel free to share your experiences with this feature and let us know how it has impacted your event configuration tasks.

SAP Cloud ALM  #Job&AutomationMonitoring #Job&AutomationMonitoringeventconfiguration #NotContains

Expert Portal

entry.title: Re: RAP on Dynamic Condition Tables ‚Äì Draft Enablement Ch...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

When dealing with dynamic tables in a RAP application, especially when draft functionality is crucial, there are several considerations and approaches you can explore:

  1. Draft Functionality in RAP:

    • Draft functionality allows users to work on temporary versions of data ABAP Restful Application Programming Model (RAP) - SAP Community before committing changes. It is typically supported in managed scenarios Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community where the CDS view is directly linked to a database table.
    • In your case, since the CDS view is implemented by a class, draft functionality is not directly supported. This is a limitation because the RAP framework requires a direct link to the database table for draft operations.

  2. Alternative Approaches:

    • Re-evaluate the CDS View Implementation: Consider if the dynamic nature of your tables can be handled differently. If possible, restructure the CDS view to directly expose the database tables, allowing draft functionality.
    • Custom Draft Handling: Implement custom logic to simulate draft behavior. This involves manually managing temporary data storage and retrieval, mimicking the draft operations.
    • Use of Side Effects: If draft functionality cannot be enabled, consider using side effects to update parent entries based on child entries dynamically.

  3. Considerations for Dynamic Data:

    • Dynamic Data Handling: Ensure that your application logic can handle changes in the underlying table structure. This might involve using dynamic SQL or flexible data models.
    • Testing and Validation: Thoroughly test the application to ensure that dynamic data handling does not introduce errors or inconsistencies.

  4. Consult Documentation and Community:

    • Review SAP documentation on RAP and draft functionality for any updates or alternative methods.
    • Engage with the SAP community to gather insights and experiences from other developers who might have faced similar challenges.

By exploring these approaches, you can find a suitable solution to enable draft functionality or effectively manage dynamic data in your RAP application.

[1] ABAP Restful Application Programming Model (RAP) - SAP Community
[2] Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Bellwethers on SAP Business Network: Key Indicators for Business - Heavy equipment
entry.content:
The New York times reported July 17 that the Consumer Price Index rose 2.7 further corroborating my observation that while freight spending on the network is up, actual freight volumes may not be keeping pace‚Äîpotentially indicating higher costs or inefficiencies. 

This inspired me to spend more time on economic bellwethers using SAP Business Network data and the new demand trends dashboard.

Heavy equipment as a Bellwether

Heavy equipment is considered an economic bellwether because demand for it closely reflects the state of major capital-intensive industries like construction, mining, infrastructure, and manufacturing‚Äîsectors that typically lead or lag the broader economy.

Heavy equipment is a long-term capital investment. Companies only purchase or lease this machinery when they‚Äôre confident in future demand, cash flow, and project pipelines.

Construction and infrastructure spending usually kick in early during economic recovery phases‚Äîmeaning equipment sales often rise before GDP growth accelerates.

Since heavy equipment is essential for site prep, grading, and material handling, it‚Äôs a leading indicator for housing starts and commercial development.

Heavy construction machinery & equipment spend on the network

Heavy equipment spend spans 5 classes on the network including earthmoving machinery, heavy equipment components building construction machinery and equipment and accessories, air lifts and paving equipment.

There a clear downward trend starting in March with a 24% drop in spending in Q2 compared to Q1. 

If current trends hold, H2 2025 spend is projected to be ~13.6% lower than H1 2025, continuing the declining pattern seen in Q2.  This does not bode well for the economy.

What are analysts saying?

According to Construction Briefing, the global construction equipment market is expected to see a decline in sales in 2025 before rebounding in the following years. This year‚Äôs anticipated 11% decline in sales reflects the damage to business confidence being done by the Trump administration‚Äôs inflationary import tariffs and the unpredictability of its policy making.

Sources:

Bellwether in business: What it is and why it matters

entry.title: Re: Journal Entry API XML example with item with 0% VAT tax
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To send a Journal Entry (JE) XML document with a 0% VAT tax value via the SAP S/4 Public Cloud API, you need to ensure that the XML structure includes the necessary tax information. Here is a sample XML structure that you can use:

<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:sfin="http://sap.com/xi/SAPSCORE/SFIN">
    <soapenv:Header/>
    <soapenv:Body>
        <sfin:JournalEntryBulkCreateRequest>
            <MessageHeader>
                <CreationDateTime>2024-03-11T10:29:20.230Z</CreationDateTime>
            </MessageHeader>
            <JournalEntryCreateRequest>
                <MessageHeader>
                    <CreationDateTime>2024-03-11T10:29:20.230Z</CreationDateTime>
                </MessageHeader>
                <JournalEntry>
                    <OriginalReferenceDocumentType>BKPFF</OriginalReferenceDocumentType>
                    <BusinessTransactionType>RFBU</BusinessTransactionType>
                    <AccountingDocumentType>KR</AccountingDocumentType>
                    <DocumentHeaderText>Test JE Posting</DocumentHeaderText>
                    <CreatedByUser>SAP</CreatedByUser>
                    <CompanyCode>1010</CompanyCode>
                    <DocumentDate>2024-03-11</DocumentDate>
                    <PostingDate>2024-03-11</PostingDate>
                    <Item>
                        <GLAccount>0063001000</GLAccount>
                        <AmountInTransactionCurrency currencyCode="EUR">1000</AmountInTransactionCurrency>
                        <DebitCreditCode>S</DebitCreditCode>
                        <Tax>
                            <TaxCode>S0</TaxCode> <!-- 0% VAT Tax Code -->
                        </Tax>
                        <AccountAssignment>
                            <CostCenter>0010101101</CostCenter>
                        </AccountAssignment>
                    </Item>
                    <ProductTaxItem>
                        <TaxCode>S0</TaxCode>
                        <TaxItemClassification>MWS</TaxItemClassification>
                        <AmountInTransactionCurrency currencyCode="EUR">0</AmountInTransactionCurrency>
                        <TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy currencyCode="EUR">1000</TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy>
                    </ProductTaxItem>
                </JournalEntry>
            </JournalEntryCreateRequest>
        </sfin:JournalEntryBulkCreateRequest>
    </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

Key Points:

  • Tax Code: Use a tax code that represents 0% VAT, such as ‚ÄòS0‚Äô.
  • ProductTaxItem Node: Ensure that the tax amount is set to 0 and the tax base amount matches the transaction amount.
  • Mandatory Fields: Include all mandatory fields such as TaxCode, TaxItemClassification, AmountInTransactionCurrency, and TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy.

If you encounter errors like ‚ÄòTax statement item missing for tax code XXX‚Äô, ensure that all required tax information is correctly filled in the ProductTaxItem node. This includes specifying the tax code and ensuring the tax amount is correctly calculated and represented.

For more detailed examples and guidelines, you can refer to the SAP Community Blog. Payload Examples for API Journal Entry ‚Äì Post - SAP Community

[1] Payload Examples for API Journal Entry ‚Äì Post - SAP Community

Kind regards, Henrike

Runtime Errors DBSQL_INVALID_CURSOR

996

entry.title: Simplifying Field Service with AI in SAP FSM
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP field service management operations set up for any new company settings requires careful planning, which has become much easier with the help of built in cloud AI features. With the help of these smart tools companies in FSM helps with much better decision making. Which also helps the technicians to complete their work more efficiently since they will be getting real-time support, faster & for instance access to the information which they require and smart scheduling. This results in lesser delays, and much improved service quality.

 Prerequisites for SAP Cloud FSM:

  • Must have a valid license for SAP AI Units.
  • Premium AI features must be activated in FSM tenant.
  • Sufficient Historical Data (1000 activities with the execution Stage should be equal to CLOSE status in order to train the system)


Key AI Features in SAP FSM:

Below is the breakdown of the core AI functionalities available

1. Intelligent Filtering

  1. Assignment Duration Prediction
  2. Activity Summary
  3. Equipment Summary

 

-> Intelligent Filtering:

Intelligent Filtering will help by showing the most relevant technicians only for the job and automatically sorting. which is like having a smart assistant that understands the input. Instead of checking each customer manually system will sort them based on the requirements of the job, then you will be getting a list of customers who passed the requirements which leads to lesser time consumption and better accuracy.
For example, imagine you're a dispatcher in FSM who is trying to assign a technician to a service job, you have list of technicians, but not all of them are suitable for all tasks, some might be far away, some might not be having the right skills, and others might already busy with other service jobs assigned previously. so based on the below points we can perform the intelligent filtering.

  • What the job needs (Like skills, tools, etc.)
  • Which technicians are available to perform the service task
  • Who is nearby to perform the service task
  • Who has done the similar job well previously.

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • Lesser time consumption: No need to manually check the list of all customers.
  • Reduced errors: Selects only technicians who are qualified and are available.
  • Improved customer service: Faster and better matches which results in the quicker resolutions for the tasks.


Steps to Enable:

  1. Raise an Incident:
    • Go to your SAP support portal.
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI.
    • Mention that you have a valid license and want to activate Intelligent Filtering.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature:
    • Once the request is processed, SAP will activate the feature in your FSM environment.
  3. Verify in the FSM Portal:
    • Navigate to the Planning & Dispatching module.
    • You‚Äôll see technician suggestions ranked intelligently when assigning service calls.

Compared to the older Best Matching Technician plugin, Intelligent Filtering is smarter and much easier to use. The old plugin works based on business rules which has been set up for every company, like checking technician skills or distance. whereas Intelligent Filtering in FSM uses the AI to understand what exactly dispatcher is looking for in the technicians and it automatically suggests the best technicians available for the service task.  It is much faster, that means it supports natural language searches. And it also gives the extra insights like past equipment history (which is not available in the old plugin doesn‚Äôt offer).


-> Assignment Duration Prediction:

Assignment Duration Prediction can be seen during the dispatching of an activity which will provide the overview like how long it will take to complete the current service task, which technician will be suitable for this activity rather than dispatcher guessing how long it might take to complete the current service tasks.

It uses the data like below:

  • The type of service task which needs to be assigned
  • The technician‚Äôs past performance on the service tasks
  • Historical data which are similar to the current service task
  • Job priority and some other requirements

This will help the dispatchers to plan accurately and helps to avoid the delay.

 Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  •  Better scheduling: can avoid the overloading the technicians.
  • Lesser delays during the assignment of service tasks.

Steps to Enable:

  1. Training the (AI Model) system

You can do this in two easy ways:

  • Option A: Use the Settings Screen
    • Go to Settings and Configuration in FSM.
    • Click on Assignment Duration Prediction.
    • Select your training data and click Train.

 

  • Option B: Use a Sample Business Rule
    • Download the sample rule from SAP Help.
    • Upload it to your FSM system.
    • Add your technical contact and adjust the date range if needed.
    • Run the rule to train the model.
  1. Activate the Feature
  • Go to: Settings and Configuration ‚Üí Planning and Dispatching ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Activity Planning ‚Üí Additional Settings
  • Turn on the checkbox:
    ‚ÄúAllow assignment duration prediction for semi and fully automated scheduling‚Äù
  1. Start Using It
  • Use features like Auto-Scheduling or Best Matching Technician.
  • The system will now use predicted durations instead of planned ones when assigning jobs.

 

-> Activity Summary:

Activity summary is like an assistant who give you the overview of the activity like what technician was doing, it gives you the summarized explanation of activity in detail, it helps the dispatcher to understand the below points:

  • what types of jobs were completed by technicians?
  • how much time did they take to complete the activity?
  • Did any issue occur during the completion of activity?


Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • with the help of activity summary dispatcher can save time as he doesn't have to go through each and every activity
  • Dispatcher can quickly understand how team is performing the activity using this feature
  • Can quickly identify if there is any issue which is occurring multiple times
  • Better decisions could be made with the help of summaries


 Steps to Enable

  1. Raise a Support Request
    • Go to the SAP Support Portal
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI
    • Mention that you want to enable Activity Summary along with other features.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature
    • Once approved, SAP will activate it in your FSM system
  3. Check in the FSM Portal
    • Go to the Planning and Dispatching module
    • You‚Äôll see AI-generated summaries for completed jobs

 

-> Equipment Summary:

Equipment Summary is similar to activity summary where in the activity summary we will be getting the summary of the completed activity but in the equipment summary we will be getting the summary of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks. it provides the details of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks which will help the dispatcher to make better decisions like.

  • Dispatcher can see which equipment was used for which service activity
  • how often did technician used this equipment
  • if there is any issue related to this equipment that can be seen in the equipment summary along with that, we can also see the performance of the equipment over time

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • it saves time by giving the summary of the equipment in an instance rather than going through the equipment history record
  • if there is any reoccurring issue that can be fixed with the help of this feature so it will be very useful for preventive maintenance activities


Steps to Enable:

  1. Go to Planning and Dispatching - Open the Planning and Dispatching module in FSM.
  2. Open a Service Call you can either click on a service call from the Dispatching Board or select one from the Service Calls list.
  3. Generate Equipment Summary
    • Inside the service call, go to the General Information tab.
    • Scroll down to the Insights section.
    • Click the button to generate the equipment summary.
  4. Review and Use the Summary
    • The system will show a short, AI-generated summary of the equipment‚Äôs history.

 

 

Conclusion:

SAP FSM‚Äôs AI features help the service teams to work much faster and smarter by reducing the manual effort and better decision making.

entry.title: Customer Invoice to Sales Order Reversal Process with Minimal Customizations
entry.content:
Backend System ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA 2020FP02

 

Business Scenario

There was a scenario where the business generated a large number of incorrect invoices due to faulty automation in the process from sales orders to invoicing. As a result, it became necessary to perform bulk operations to cancel the invoices, reverse the PGIs, delete the deliveries, and reject the associated sales orders. To address this unique situation, a solution was provided with minimal customization.

 

  • Bulk Invoice Cancelation

A LSMW was provided to handle the cancellation of the identified invoices. The relevant user was able to upload the necessary invoice data and perform bulk cancellations efficiently.

 

  • PGI Reversal

As a solution for the PGI reversal, a custom upload program was developed using the standard BAPI WS_REVERSE_GOODS_ISSUE. Users could upload an Excel file in the required format and execute the program to reverse the PGIs in bulk. The program also included a test run option to help identify any potential issues with the deliveries before performing the actual reversal.

The main reason for developing this custom solution was a specific business requirement: the ability to reverse PGIs based on the posting date, which is not feasible in standard transaction VL09 for bulk processing.

While VL09 allows individual PGI reversals and provides the option to change the reversal date, it does not support bulk processing. Hence, a custom solution was necessary to meet the business requirement for reversing multiple PGIs at once with the ability to specify a reversal date.

 

  • Delevery Deletion and Sales Order Rejection

Delivery deletion and sales order rejection can be performed simultaneously using transaction code VKM4. Deliveries that have already been reversed can be deleted through this transaction. On the selection screen, the delivery numbers should be entered in the 'SD Document' field, and the 'Deliveries' checkbox must be selected to ensure proper filtering and execution.

 

The user can then execute transaction VKM4. On the next screen, the 'Processing Status' checkbox should be selected, and the user should choose the 'Reject' option to proceed with the delivery deletion and sales order rejection.

 

The user has the option to decide whether to perform both delivery deletion and sales order rejection simultaneously, or to carry out only the delivery deletion. Based on the requirement, if both actions are needed, the user must select a rejection reason from the search help, click the 'Copy' button, and then click 'Save' to complete the process. In this case, the entire sales order will be rejected using the rejection reason specified in VKM4.

 

 

On the other hand, if the user's requirement is to delete only the delivery without rejecting the sales order, the 'Reason for Rejection' field should be left empty and no value should be selected from the search help. As with the previous case, the user should then click the 'Copy' button followed by the 'Save' button to complete the delivery deletion process.

 

Special thanks to the @Chathuranga_Rajapaksha

entry.title: SAP EWM - Deconsolidation of Handling Unit Internally in Warehouse
entry.content:
The deconsolidation process involves dividing the larger shipment into smaller units, checking their accuracy and condition, and preparing them for final delivery. Efficient load deconsolidation is vital to ensure accurate inventory management, reduce errors and improve overall efficiency. Deconsolidation activity is observed in various industries such as Food & Beverages, Textile, Fashion, Retail, Automotive and Aftermarket sales etc. Deconsolidation in EWM is mainly observed during Inbound but can be performed as an Internal activity as well. 

I have attempted to showcase how it can be achieved in the SAP EWM. 

Configuration:

1) Define Storage types 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Define Storage Types

Storage type where stock is putawayed when received in a warehouse.

Deconsolidation Work center storage type.

Storage where deconsolidated stock will be kept, from where stock will be picked directly for outbound orders.

Create Activity area, Create Bins and do Bin sorting. 

2) Define POSC

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings> Warehouse Task> Define Process-Oriented Storage Control

3) Define Work Center 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Work Center > Define Work Center

Assign storage process for deconsolidation.

4) Define Strategies for Stock Removal and Putaway

a) Removal Strategy

SCM EWM> EWM> Goods Issue Process > Strategies > Specify Storage Type Search Sequence

b) Putaway Strategy 

SCM EWM > EWM > Goods Receipt Process > Strategies > Storage Type Search> Define Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

Assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence

Specify Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

5) Define Warehouse Process type

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings > Warehouse Task > Define Warehouse Process Type

Assign Storage process in warehouse process type.

Master Data:

Use T code /SCWM/TWORKST to maintain Workcenter Bin

Testing:

1) Use T code /SCWM/ADHU to create a warehouse task for a mix Handling Unit.Enter HU number and click on execute. Click on Create/ Create+Save, HU will be picked, and warehouse task will be created move HU to Deconsolidation Workcenter. 

Confirm open Warehouse task and HU will be moved to Deconsolidation work center.

2) Use /SCWM/DCONS to open Deconsolidation work center.

Create new Handling units and pack quantity into new Handling unit.

Once deconsolidation completed, Click on Complete Process step for HU. 

Note: Recommended to complete HU step one by one to avoid locking. 

HU labels can be printed and pasted. Click on Refresh a new WT will be created to move HU to Final storage. 

All the above steps can be performed in RFUI as well.

entry.title: Re: Regarding cross Tier , Cross 'ABAP Language" Cloud de...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

Implementing a classic unreleased BADI by writing the core logic in a Tier-1 class and using a Tier-2 wrapper class to wrap any unreleased objects is a strategic approach to minimize technical debt. This method allows you to prepare for future upgrades by ensuring that your logic is already in a cloud-ready format once the BADI is released. However, there are some considerations:

  1. Cross-Tier Compatibility: Ensure that the Tier-1 class and Tier-2 wrapper are compatible with the Tier-3 BADI. This involves checking that the interfaces and data types used are consistent across tiers.

  2. Upgrade Stability: While this approach is designed to enhance upgrade stability, it is crucial to test thoroughly to ensure that the integration between tiers does not introduce unexpected issues during upgrades.

  3. Documentation and Guidelines: SAP provides guidelines on using tiers for extensibility, but specific documentation for your approach might not be available. It is recommended to follow SAP‚Äôs general guidelines for extensibility ABAP Cloud ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA extensibility ‚Äì May 2023 ‚Ä¶ - SAP Community and API usage.

Unfortunately, there is no specific SAP Note, KBA, or blog that directly supports this approach. However, the concept of using tiers for extensibility SAP S/4HANA Extensibility Options For Clean Core J‚Ä¶ - SAP Community is discussed in various SAP resources, emphasizing the importance of using released APIs and extension points for upgrade stability.

[1] ABAP Cloud ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA extensibility ‚Äì May 2023 ... - SAP Community
[2] SAP S/4HANA Extensibility Options For Clean Core J... - SAP Community
Kind regards, 
Henrike

entry.title: Re: How to delete an entry in the Landscape Management, w...
entry.content:
Hello,

for the Service Type "SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Environment" I would expect that these services have the Source: Imported.
You can verify this in the Details Section in LMS.

If my assumption is correct, then it is not possible to delete these systems manually. Only systems/services with the Source "Manual" or "Registered" can be manually deleted.

For other imported services (from SLIS) the process is as follows: They will be marked as deleted once the customer unsubscribes. They will be deleted with the next SLIS import once all use cases have the status "Not Configured" and all endpoints are deleted. Please refer to
Troubleshooting for Landscape Management 

If endpoints and Use Cases are clean, it can be expected that they should be gone soon. 

Best regards
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Customer Invoice to Sales Order Reversal Process with Minimal Customizations
entry.content:
To be honest, I am not clear with your post as to why the entire process to be reversed. Please answer the following:

  1. Was the customer information incorrect (e.g., wrong ship-to or bill-to party)?
  2. Did the invoice reflect the wrong material or product?
  3. Was the pricing condition misapplied (e.g., discounts, surcharges)?
  4. Were the taxes or duties calculated incorrectly?
  5. Was the currency incorrect or mismatched with the sales order?
  6. Were invoices created for sales orders that were not yet approved or released?
  7. Did the automation trigger invoices for orders that were meant to be blocked or rejected?
  8. Were duplicate invoices generated for the same sales order?
  9. Did the system create invoices for cancelled or already invoiced orders?
  10. Was there a mismatch between delivery quantity and invoiced quantity?
  11. Were invoices raised for partial deliveries that weren‚Äôt supposed to be billed yet?


Based on your answers to above query, a right direction can be shown

entry.title: Long running phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I in ECC to S/4 conversion using DMOVE to S/4 with Do-DMO
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, I will share the details of the issue, troubleshooting steps, and the solution that helped me resolve  the long running phase: PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I during conversion in SUM tool.

During a recent ECC to SAP S/4HANA 2023 conversion project using DMO with System Move (DoDMO), we encountered a major performance bottleneck.
The SUM phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I, which typically should not take very long, ended up running for more than 30 hours without completing.

 

Background

  • Source system: ECC 6 EHP 8 on DB2 v11.5.9.0
  • Target system: S/4HANA 2023 FPS01
  • SUM version: SUM 2.0 SP23
  • Method: DMOVE to S/4 using DoDMO
  • OS version: SLES 15 SP05 (both Source and target)

The conversion was progressing smoothly until the phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I.

The Issue:

During the conversion, Software Update Manager (SUM) entered the phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I and it was running very slow.

This phase is part of the preparation import steps and is mainly responsible for:

  • Importing tool-related transport objects into the shadow system.
  • These objects are necessary for SUM to run subsequent phases.
  • It typically involves R3trans and tp calls that execute DDIC and tool transports.

Expected Behavior

  • Normally, this step should finish within a few min to hour (depending on system size and DB performance).

The logs (TOOLIMP_I.LOG) should show a sequence of transport requests being imported with steady progress.

 

How we Overcame the Issue

After confirming that the TOOLIMP_I phase was progressing extremely slowly with no obvious system bottleneck, I decided to take corrective action. Below are the exact steps that resolved the issue.

Terminate Processes

  • Killed all R3trans and tp put processes running on the Additional Application Server (AAS) where SUM was initiated.
  • Also killed the SAPup process on the AAS to terminate the running phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I.

Ensure DIR_PUT Consistency

  • The parameter DIR_PUT (checked in transaction RZ11) must be consistent between the Primary Application Server (PAS) and the AAS.

Example: DIR_PUT = /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap
In my case, SUM was started from a different mount point on AAS:
/Migration/SUM
To fix this, I created a soft link under /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM pointing to the /Migration/SUM directory.

Copy SUM Directory

  • Copied the entire SUM directory from the AAS to PAS on below location
    /usr/sap/<SID>/

Adjust TOOLIMPI.TPP

Edit the file: /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/var/TOOLIMPI.TPP on the PAS and make sure its points correctly to PAS folders and files. Below is the screenshot showing how the file was correctly edited on PAS.

What is TOOLIMPI.TPP?

  • This is the tp parameter profile for the TOOLIMP_I phase.
  • It tells the tp tool how to perform the transport import.
  • SUM generates this dynamically for each import phase.
  • Key things it controls include: transport directory paths, buffer handling, import options, trace level, and return codes.

Clean Up Old TMP Files

  • Navigate to /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/tmp/
    Deleted/renamed all files starting with SAPI*. These files were remnants of the failed run on AAS, and new ones would be generated for the PAS-based execution in below steps

Manually Trigger tp Import

  • Executed the tp command manually on PAS in dialog mode:
    tp pf=/usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/var/TOOLIMPI.TPP put <SID>
    This command performed the transport import for TOOLIMP_I runs in dialog, wait for the command to complete successfully, it has taken 1:15 hour in our case.
    Meanwhile, new log files were generated under the tmp directory.

Sync Buffer File from PAS to AAS

  • Once the manual import finished, the buffer file in SUM directory of AAS was replaced with buffer file in the SUM directory of PAS:
    Buffer file location: /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/buffer/<SID>
    Copied this updated buffer file back to the SUM directory in AAS from SUM directory in PAS to ensure consistency.

Resume SUM on the AAS

  • Return to the SUM URL.
  • Selected ‚ÄúRepeat Phase‚Äù (not ‚ÄúStart from Beginning‚Äù).

SUM Moves On to next phase

  • SUM recognized from the updated buffer file that the TOOLIMP_I phase had already completed successfully and proceeded to next phase.

Result:

  • The long runtime in PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I during my DoDMO-based S/4HANA conversion was a valuable lesson in how even ‚Äúpreparation‚Äù phases can turn into critical bottlenecks. By carefully analyzing SUM behavior, ensuring environment consistency, and using controlled manual intervention, I was able to resolve an issue that had stalled for more than 30 hours and guide SUM back on track. This experience reinforced the importance of understanding SUM‚Äôs internal processes, maintaining flexibility in troubleshooting, and always preparing for unexpected challenges during complex system conversions.

Hello @SivaNagiReddy 

Thank you for raising this. In the Import Supplier Invoice app India localisation: the template design does not include fields for place.  of Supply or Withholding Tax. These values are obtained from supplier master data or must be entered directly in the Create Supplier Invoice app.

If you are receiving the error 'Place of supply is not determined,' you can alter this behaviour to a warning or informational message through SSCUI 101923 ‚Äì Message Control (message ID J_1IG_MSGS 015), enabling invoice posting to proceed.

Check SAP KBA Below

  • SAP KBA 3509454 ‚Äì Error ‚ÄúPlace of Supply not determined‚Äù in Import Supplier Invoice

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: VK13 issue
entry.content:
Go to v/07 and check all the fields used in the first access sequence are correctly mapped and active. From technical angle, sometimes, a field like LAND1 may be mapped incorrectly to LAND1Z, which causes it to disappear from the display in VK13

Sometimes, the TR would not have imported properly into production. Check in VK+C and regenerate the condition table if needed. Check VAKEY as per this discussion

entry.title: Re: Launching My Custom SAPUI5 App in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @marceloromeiro 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, you cannot create a custom tile directly by simply pasting the deployed app URL and linking it to a Z-catalogue. The supported method is to utilise the Custom Catalogue Extensions and Custom Tiles functionality within the Launchpad Designer.

Deploy your RAP/UI5 app ‚Äì you have already done this. It should be visible within the deployed HTML5 applications.

Create a customised business catalogue (Z-catalogue) using the Maintain Catalogue Extensions app.

Create a custom tile using the Manage Launchpad Apps app (not a direct URL). Select your deployed app from the list of available apps.

Assign the app to your custom Z-catalogue via the same app.

Finally, assign the catalogue to the relevant business role in Maintain Business Roles so that users see the tile in their Launchpad.

You need to register the deployed UI5 app as a Launchpad App and assign it through a Z-catalogue created via the in-app extensibility tools. Directly linking a URL to a catalogue is not supported in Public Cloud

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

What‚Äôs New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

 

Next Steps:

Learn more about the SAP Application Extension Methodology on the SAP Help Portal.

Learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework on the SAP Discovery Center and look out for the continuation of the blog post series. The next one will be about Data&Analytics.

Learn more about Clean Core by reading our detailed whitepaper, or tune into our latest Unlocking SAP BTP podcast episode focusing on clean core.

Feel free to like, comment and ask your questions!

Talk to you soon,
Marco

Product Manager SAP Business Technology Platform

Join me online: https://www.linkedin.com/in/marcomatha/

entry.title: Re: SAC Scripting
entry.content:
@shiva1233 

/ Assuming your table is named "Table_1" and your dropdown is "Dropdown_1"
// And the dimension you are filtering is "YourDimension"
To set the dropdown with filter values from table, the dropdown should have those values as possible selection. I will assume that you already have it.

Adjust accordingly

// Reading the Table filters
var oFilter = Table_1.getDataSource().getDimensionFilters("yourDimension");
console.log(["getFilter ",oFilter]);
var strFilter = [""];


if (oFilter[0].type === FilterValueType.Single){
	var sfv = cast(Type.SingleFilterValue,oFilter[0]);
	var strFilter = [sfv.value];
}
else{
	var mfv = cast(Type.MultipleFilterValue,oFilter[0]);
	for (var i=0, len=mfv.values.length; i< len; i++){
		strFilter.push(mfv.values[i]);
	}
	
}


Dropdown_1.setSelectedKey(strFilter)

Nikhil

ExportToPdf Cannot find "CRToWords.DLL".

entry.title: Strengthening Financial Master Data with CDQ's Bank Account API: Real-Time Fraud Detection in MDG
entry.content:
Executive Summary 

Organizations face an increasing risk of fraud in vendor payments and financial master data. This blog introduces a lightweight SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) enhancement that integrates CDQ's Bank Account API to validate bank trustworthiness and detect fraud ‚Äî in real-time ‚Äî directly within the Change Request process. 

 

Introduction

Data quality in financial master data plays a crucial role in maintaining integrity and trust across the enterprise. Especially with increasing cases of fraud targeting bank account information, it has become vital to validate this data against trusted external sources. This blog post demonstrates how to integrate CDQ's Bank Account Data API into SAP MDG to detect and warn about known fraud cases in real time during the Change Request process. 

 

Background

Corporate Data Quality (CDQ) is a cloud-based platform that enables organizations to access verified, trusted data by connecting to official and commercial registers worldwide. While it is widely used for sourcing company information such as legal names, tax numbers, and registration data, CDQ also offers APIs for verifying bank accounts, which play a growing role in fraud prevention and financial data governance.

In my previous blog post, I demonstrated how to create a custom DPI integration solution in SAP for Business Partner creation using a Custom List UIBB and REST API calls to CDQ. This blog builds on that architectural pattern, extending it to the bank account domain using CDQ‚Äôs Bank Account Data API to validate and assess trust levels of banks directly within the Change Request process.

 

Feasible Option - Abstract

SAP MDG Classic Mode does not natively support dynamic bank account validation using external risk intelligence. However, this limitation can be overcome by integrating CDQ‚Äôs Bank Account Data API into the Change Request (CR) process via a custom-built API integration. This enables the following capabilities:

  • Fraud Detection: Detect if a bank is blacklisted or associated with a known fraud case.
  • Reputation Scoring: Retrieve and display the bank accounts' trust score for transparency and risk assessment.
  • Real-Time Messaging: Show contextual messages ‚Äî either warnings (blacklisted) or information (whitelisted) ‚Äî directly in the UI during CR processing.

For example:
If a blacklisted bank is entered: ‚ö†Ô∏è Bank & is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: &

Figure 1 ‚Äì Warning message after a bank in the blacklist is entered

 If a whitelisted bank is used with a known trust score: ‚úÖ Bank & is in whitelist, trust score: &

Figure 2 ‚Äì Information message after a bank in the whitelist is entered

This solution provides a feasible, low-effort, and value-driven way to bring real-time banking insights into your SAP MDG environment.

 

Some Nice-To-Have Skills

Here are some nice-to-have skills and knowledge areas for handling this topic:

ABAP programming, T-Code: SM59, SM30, STRUST, USMD_RULE_SERVICE BadI Definition, REST API, RFC, MDG

 

Solution in a Nutshell

This solution enhances SAP MDG's Change Request process by verifying bank account data in real time via CDQ‚Äôs Bank Account Data API. The goal is to detect potential fraud or confirm the trustworthiness of a bank at the moment it is entered in the Change Request.

Here's how it works:

  1. The user adds a bank account in a CR (only IBAN or bank account number & bank code/number & bank country code).
  2. Upon entry, background logic triggers a call to CDQ‚Äôs Bank Account Data API (POST /v2/bankaccounts/confirm).
  3. The response returns whether the bank:
    • ‚úÖIs in the whitelist, along with a trust score (e.g., trustScore: 27).
    • ‚ö†Ô∏èHas one or more fraud cases, with related metadata like fraudCaseId.
  4. SAP MDG then displays a contextual message in the UI based on the result:
    • If the bank is whitelisted: ‚úÖ Bank 0002 is in whitelist, trust score: 27
    • If the bank is flagged for fraud: ‚ö†Ô∏è Bank 0001 is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: UUIK5gGCQD

This provides immediate, actionable feedback to master data stewards before the data is activated, reducing the risk of onboarding risky bank accounts.

 

Implementation Steps

For our solution, we pursued the following steps:

  • Create an API Key Instance from CDQ with a Client ID and Client Secret. For more information, please visit this site.
  • Import TLS root certificate for https://api.cdq.com. For more information, check out this blog.
  • Maintain the required RFC Destinations to set up technical communication.
  • Determine the logical port as the DPI‚Äôs general RFC Destination. Configure the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view in SM30.
  • Create these classes to implement the logic;
    1. API Caller Class (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER) -> Handling API requests, communicating with CDQ
    2. Main Integration Class (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION) -> Prepare the request data and trigger the POST method
    3. Validation Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_VALIDATION) -> Display the outcome of the API in Change Request
    4. Utilities Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_UTILITIES) -> Collect useful methods that are used several times

Create New API Key;

Figure 3 ‚Äì Generating API Key from CDQ Portal for Secure Integration

To establish secure HTTPS communication with CDQ, the certificate for api.cdq.com must be imported via transaction STRUST. This is depicted in Figure 4, where the certificate is added under the SSL Client (Standard);

Figure 4 ‚Äì Certification for CDQ API

Set up External Server HTTP Connections;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Figure 5 ‚Äì RFC Connections for CDQ

The created RFC Destination Z_DPI_CDQ is assigned as the logical port for DPI‚Äôs general operation. You can see this configuration in Figure 6, which shows the entry in the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view;

 

 

 

 


Figure 6 ‚Äì Data entry for V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST to determine logical port for general DPI operations

Remark: The following methods will be the main part of the framework, they do not include the whole picture.

The method responsible for communicating with CDQ (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER->CALL_API);

  METHOD call_api.

    TRY.
        DATA(rfc_destination) = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-general-name ).

        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          DATA(http_client) = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).

          cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri( request = http_client->request
                                            uri     = api_path ).

          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error.
        rfc_destination = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-lookup-name ).
        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          http_client = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).
          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.
        IF rest_client IS INITIAL.
          RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( textid = cx_mdqdpi_functional_error=>data_provider_setup_error ).
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

    DATA(request) = build_request( payload = payload
                                   mapping = mapping ).
    rest_client->post( request ).
    result = rest_client->get_response_entity( )->get_string_data( ).
    analyze_response(
      EXPORTING
        string_response  = result
        rest_client      = rest_client                 " REST Client
      IMPORTING
        http_status_code = http_status_code
    ).

    rest_client->close( ).
    CLEAR rest_client.

  ENDMETHOD.

 The method responsible for preparing the API response for validation BAdI (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION->BANK_RELIABILITY);

  METHOD bank_reliability.

    DATA:
      ls_abap_format  TYPE zif_cdq_bp_integration=>gty_bank_reliability_response,
      ls_t100_message TYPE scx_t100key.

    CLEAR:
      ev_status,
      es_cdq_bank_response,
      et_t100_message.

    DATA(name_mappings) = VALUE /ui2/cl_json=>name_mappings( ( abap = 'bank_code'      json = 'nationalBankIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'iban'           json = 'internationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'account_number' json = 'nationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'bic'            json = 'internationalBankIdentifier' ) ).

    DATA(api_caller) = zcl_cdq_api_caller=>get_instance( ).

    TRY.
        api_caller->call_api(
          EXPORTING
            api_path         = '/sap-odm/v3/bankaccount-data/rest/v2/bankaccounts/confirm'
            payload          = is_cdq_bank_request
            mapping          = name_mappings                 " ABAP<->JSON Name Mapping Table
          IMPORTING
            result           = DATA(http_response)
            http_status_code = ev_status
        ).

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error INTO DATA(lx_error).

*     General error message info
        CLEAR ls_t100_message.
        ls_t100_message = lx_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
        go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
          EXPORTING
            ix_error        = lx_error                 " Functional Errors
          CHANGING
            cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
        ).
        IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
          APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
        ENDIF.

*     Detailed error message info if exists
        IF lx_error->previous IS NOT INITIAL.
          CLEAR ls_t100_message.
          DATA(lx_previos_error) = CAST cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( lx_error->previous ).
          ls_t100_message = lx_previos_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
          go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
            EXPORTING
              ix_error        = lx_previos_error                 " Functional Errors
            CHANGING
              cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
          ).
          IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
            APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
        EXIT.
    ENDTRY.

    convert_to_abap_format(
      EXPORTING
        iv_data_in_json_format       = http_response
        iv_api_type                  = 'BANK_REL'                 " LOOK_UP / BANK_REL / EMAIL
      IMPORTING
        es_cdq_bank_response = es_cdq_bank_response                 " Bank Reliability Response Type
    ).

*  If the bank account has no trust score or fraud case, the bank account is unknown for CDQ
    IF      es_cdq_bank_response-trust_score            IS INITIAL
        AND es_cdq_bank_response-associated_fraud_cases IS INITIAL.
      es_cdq_bank_response-is_bank_unkown  = abap_true.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

Conclusion

As organizations increasingly rely on external banking data for payments, compliance, and onboarding, trusted bank account validation becomes a critical part of financial master data governance. This integration with CDQ‚Äôs Bank Account Data API provides SAP MDG users with real-time insights into the trust level and potential fraud risk of a bank‚Äîbefore the data is activated.

By embedding this verification into the Change Request process:

  • Stewards are empowered to act immediately on risks.
  • Fraud-prone banks can be flagged and avoided.
  • Clean, verified bank accounts improve downstream processes like payments and compliance reporting.

This approach not only enhances data quality and integrity but also supports key organizational goals: minimizing risk, preventing fraud, and building a solid foundation for digital finance processes.

Whether in finance, procurement, or vendor onboarding, this solution helps ensure that the bank accounts you rely on are exactly what they claim to be: trusted.

entry.title: Re: Complex Multi-Rater Performance Rating Overall Calculations in SAP SuccessFactors Integration Ce
entry.content:
@Berg_Song Hi!

 Thank you very much for your response.

We focus on the overall evaluation because the objectives are also assessed on a scale from 1 to 5. With that overall score, we move on to compensation. We cannot evaluate competencies on a scale from 1 to 5 because, for succession planning, we need the score relative to the expected value in order to make comparisons. Therefore, we see that the evaluation method required for succession and the overall score used for compensation, which considers objectives, do not use the same metric.

Best regards

entry.title: Full Payment Submission Amendment reversal
entry.content:
Hi,

We have submitted an FPSA with the incorrect Payroll Period.  

How do we reverse this?  The FPSA was only to include Class 1A value on termination payments.  Is it correct that we submit an FPSA again, but this time with a -ve value of the class 1A, include the same payroll period?

Then, when we submit the FPSA again, use the correct Payroll Period and a +ve Class 1A value?

I remember from years ago, but perhaps it was an EYU that you placed an 'X' somewhere in the upload template and this reverses the submission?

Michael

entry.title: Re: In a script, how do I check if an LDM Entity is a subtype?
entry.content:
Hi George,

I just checked my PD 16.7 SP07 PL02 documentation. It states that EntityAttribute (LDM) has InheritedFrom and InheritanceSource properties (not collections!) and both contain the EntityAttribute from the parent entity (meaning they are inherited).
An Entity has SuperEntities and InheritsFrom collections. The first contains all parent entities, and the second contains collections of InheritanceLinks.

So, by checking each attribute for:

  • not having an InheritedFrom property defined (i.e., Nothing)
    AND

  • not being part of the Primary Key (PrimaryIdentifier property)

you should get your list of logical attributes to export. This seems achievable to me, but maybe I am missing something from your description. See my example on the screenshot below.

Here is my code:

For each e in activemodel.entities
  output "============"  
  output e.name
  output "-------------"
  If not (e.ParentEntity is Nothing) then
    output "Parent entity: " + e.PArentEntity
  End if
  For each se in e.SuperEntities          ' collection
    output "SuperEntities: " + se.Name + " (" + se.ObjectType + ")"
  Next
  For each ifr in e.InheritsFrom
    'output "InheritsFrom: " + ifr.Name + " (" + ifr.OBjectType + ")"
  Next
  
  output "-------------"
  For each a in e.Attributes
    output a.Name & " - " & a.PrimaryIdentifier
    If not (a.InheritedFrom is Nothing) then        ' just property
      output "inherited From: " + a.InheritedFrom + " (" + a.InheritedFrom.ObjectType + ")"
    End if
    If not (a.InheritanceSource is Nothing) then    ' just property
      output "inheritanceSource: " + a.InheritanceSource  + " (" + a.InheritanceSource.ObjectType + ")"
    End if
  Next
Next

 

Let me know,
Ondrej

P.S. "Pravda" stands for True and "Nepravda" for False in my Output window.
